landlord_tenant_relationship.reasoning: Complaint alleges a written lease beginning June 1, 2022, for the residential apartment at 123 Maple Street and monthly rent paid to Defendant (¶¶2, 4). These facts plainly establish a landlord–tenant relationship.

act_or_omission_by_landlord.reasoning: Complaint alleges specific landlord actions/omissions: placing a few snap traps, authorizing only a single exterminator visit, refusing recommended comprehensive building-wide treatment, and blaming the tenant (¶¶7, 9–10, 22). Those are affirmative acts and omissions by the landlord.

substantial_interference.reasoning: Complaint alleges recurring mouse droppings beginning ~September 2025 and continuing weekly (¶5–7), contamination of food requiring disposal (¶11), purchases to protect food (¶11), and ongoing stress, anxiety, and loss of use/enjoyment of the kitchen/home (¶12, 13, 23). These factual allegations support a claim of substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.

causation.reasoning: Complaint alleges the tenant notified the landlord and requested remediation (¶6, 14), the exterminator recommended comprehensive treatment (¶9), and the landlord’s refusal to authorize/pay for that treatment led to continued infestation and interference (¶10–13, 21–22). Those allegations link the landlord’s conduct/omission to the ongoing interference.

damages.reasoning: Complaint pleads specific out‑of‑pocket economic losses (about $200 in discarded food and $80 for food storage containers) (¶11, 23) and non‑economic harms (stress, anxiety, loss of use/enjoyment) (¶12, 23), satisfying the pleading requirement for damages.
